headline: High quality courses, terrible quality website
reviewBody:
Good quality videos and courses, however both the offline player and website have constant massive technical issues and bugs:

* Very expensive compared to similar sites, which would be justified if not for all of the bugs on Pluralsight's end.

* Online player buffers the clip completely, but then consistently and frequently stutters every few seconds. I have found no way to fix as supposedly with the clip fully buffered, it shouldn't occur.

* Very slow server responses, signing up and joining can be a 30 minute wait, after paying ~£25pcm I had to wait for almost 40minutes to be able to access any content.

* The offline player has even more bugs, such as corrupted audio for clips, not recognising you are a paid member or even logged on to access the content.

* The offline player also doesn't play clips at certain speeds, meaning you have to change the speed of the video to watch it, and then change it again for the next clip. This can be very frustrating when each clip is generally only a few minutes long

* I have tried to provide feedback on these issues multiple times, but never had any feedback or assistance for how to possibly remedy any of these, or even help on what I may be doing wrong.

headline: Underhanded scammers
reviewBody:
Like many other businesses, I have had to navigate my business through very difficult trading conditions in the last 9 months due to the global pandemic, including having to regrettably make many redundancies. 
On Sept 10th I received from my Account Manager an "Early renewal - offer". I contacted him within few days saying that I was not interested in renewing due to company financial situation. However, I was informed that I was too late. 
It turns out that, even though I received a "Early renewal offer" on Sept 10th, this was in fact the last day to submit a cancellation request for my company's subscription. No prior comms (calls or emails) were sent to me to inform me of the upcoming annual renewal.
Despite my numerous emails, my so called account manager did not send a single reply. 
I have instead started receiving emails from their Account Receivables department informing me that my renewal invoice was past due. 
I have tried to reason with them that, given the current market conditions, they should have informed me of the upcoming renewal, that I had in fact cancelled my subscription ahead of renewal date and that if they persisted with this they will not be paid any time soon.
I have asked to speak to someone in their management team, but instead I was threatened with our case being referred to a credit collection agency.
I think it is extremely underhanded to rely on the excuse of an autorenewal clause without the shadow of customer notice or any other comms. I understand everyone is fighting to survive, but this is not the way to do it.
I will not be paying this people and I will be happy to fight them in court.
It is a shame, my team enjoyed their platform and I would have signed up again once business goes back to normal. They have instead lost a customer and by the look of other reviews many more in addition to mine.

headline: Dishonourable Business Practices
reviewBody:

I was regularly called by an account rep, and before our account expired I informed the rep that we would not be renewing our subscription. I wrote to the account manager on at least one occasion saying the same, with no reply.

A month later, and after many more past due-invoices, I was contacted by their billing department, threatening to report us to a credit agency. I explained the situation and was told that we had to opt-out in writing 60 days before our one-year subscription ended. Why didn't the rep tell me this or return my email? 

Be very wary when entering into a contract with Pluralsight.

headline: The almost perfect learning platform for digital skills
reviewBody:
It is an amazing platform and almost everything I need I can find it there. However, drawing and sketching are highly valuable skills, which are loosely covered here - even though the creative path is probably one of the best on the internet. 
I would also like to see more business and digital-marketing orientated classes here as well.

The other thing which really bothers me is the badly structured subscription plans they have - for example, for the practice-based classes you can have access to them only by a premium subscription - which is entirely based on a Y2Y basis, not month by month. 
This is a more than odd decision by their marketers, as the kind of people who will most probably benefit from this service are such that they still don't have the necessary skills and earnings to spend so much on a course which was supposed to be designed for amateurs. If there was a monthly based premium subscription I was most probably going to pay extra for it and it really annoys me.

TL;DR - great platform, really handy, but for me lacking enough coverage for creative and digital marketing paths, as well as the proper payment plans that suit your target audience the best.

reviewBody: CEO Aaron Skonnard has a listed net worth of $21-million. Yet from the looks of things on this site, while things are going sweet for him, something is going sour at Pluralsight. While the content of courses looks generally good, or even great, I recently had a billing issue which seemed shockingly shady. I signed up in December and then cancelled in February, only because I got busy with other things and couldn't make full use of the service. My CC got billed the following month. I went to their user portal to check my account status; my account was still "active" but my subscription status was dropped down to "free" which basically meant that I could log in to the site but couldn't watch any course videos. I assumed that maybe the billing period had reached its border earlier or later than I thought, but I was billed the next month again. I contacted customer service, and they ended up clearing the issue up, but I still think it should not have happened in the first place. Having worked in production at a SAAS start-up, and after reading all these reviews, it's hard for me to imagine this kind of "error" is not something of a deliberation coming from upper management or a higher-level sales & revenue initiative. If it's merely a software engineering issue, it's still a pretty bad one and should have been fixed very promptly after customers started reporting it.

Since I don't use Pluralsight anymore, I decided to just cancel the subscription. 

Their customer service agent then informs me that they bill for the next full year, and "per our Terms of Service" cannot offer a refund. Even though the request was sent within hours of the charge.

Wow!!!

Clearly this failing business makes their money by sneak attacking customers into renewing year after year, unless they mark their calendars to cancel, or pay for a full year of service and cancel their account with nothing to show for it.

headline: Negative Review for Pluralsight
reviewBody:
Beware! I am writing this negative review for pluralsight specifically about their auto renewal contract.  Most companies auto renewals go month to month after the first year.  We just got billed for a full new year with their auto-renewal with really no notice. This was a $ 4,000 hit to our credit card.  We reached out to Plural account representative only to have him say they could do nothing about it "sorry".  I read their terms and conditions and it does state that it does auto renew and there is no refunds. 

I have been in the IT service business for 30 years and I have never seen this kind of tactic.  Great way to loose a client.  There are some specific laws in CA that protect us from auto renewals which I will be using to get our money back. This Pluralsight policy is written to specifically screw people, so I would be careful working with this company before you sign with them.

Update: 10-4-2018
Reversed charges with credit card,  sent email to sales representative and their legal department with no reply.  Pluralsight billed us again with no communication.  Visa is now blocking their account.

headline: Good content - Horrible customer service
reviewBody:
Pluralsight has great content on a wide variety of topics.
Unfortunately, this is overshadowed by their incredibly poor customer service.
Our company was on an annual subscription and received an invoice 15 days prior to our renewal. The invoice showed a significant increase over the previous year. We immediately tried to contact them to work out a solution. For the first contact, it took them over a week to get back to us. After several days of being unable to work out a compromise on price and/or reduction in licenses, we decided to cancel.
At that point, we were told we were not able to cancel since cancellation needed to be done 30 prior to the renewal.
We have pointed out time and time again that we tried to work with them immediately after being notified of the price increase (which was also given to us after the cancellation deadline had passed).
Their training material is good, and they don't need to rely on these unreasonable practices to try to force customers into paying for what they don't want or need.

headline: Do not be an Instructor
reviewBody:
Pluralsight contacted me to be an instructor.  My curriculum was approved and I was promised a $200 reimbursement for equipment (microphone and stand, digital adapter) and software I had to buy (which went over this allotted amount).  I spent time planning my lessons and had audio trouble that the editor they set me up with was not able to help me resolve.  As a full time employee, I needed to work on this project when I had pockets of time.  Waiting for feedback was very slow and didn't work out with my schedule.  I asked to be able to work with a more responsive editor, but was denied. I moved to another state and brought all this equipment with me, as well as a different laptop (which would probably resolve the audio issues).  Soon after, I was told my project was cancelled.  I asked for the $200 reimbursement- not any $ for my time or moving expenses or anything else.  I was told by the editor that I would get it.  I corresponded with him monthly, reminding him of the money owed to me.  This went on for 5 months before I gave up.  I do not recommend working with or purchasing from a company with these poor business ethics.

Also- I have used Pluralsight for training myself and have found that a lot of the content is outdated and obsolete. It is difficult to find the software version on the courses.  They seemed to have a lot more relevant content when they were Digital Tutors.  Some of this content has been moved over to the new Pluralsight, but a lot of it is missing.

headline: Their customer service is the worse
reviewBody:
Their customer service is the worse.   My credit card was expiring end of September.   I wanted to change the card to a different card.   BUT!    Pluralsight decided to change my profile with an updated expiration date of the old card.   Now, I asked where in TOS they had to right to change my profile - they blamed my bank.   I asked a second time - they said they had a right to collect fees... even if the card was still valid for the current billing cycle WHICH HADN'T HAPPENED YET.   I pointed this out and asked a third time and was told "because they can do anything they want".   Really?  Seriously?

So I canceled the account and subscription which meant they never got a chance to bill me for a cycle on which the original card was still valid.

Bottom line - NO ONE has the right, unless spelled out in TOS, to change my profile or billing profile WITHOUT my permission.   And NO ONE has the arrogant right to tell me "because they can" - they can take their website and shove it.

You can also test your skills, by taking quizzes and tests to determine your knowledge on a specific area, pluralsight tells you how much you have improved and which courses to look over. headline: Combined Quality of Tutorials
reviewBody:
Back when DigitalTutors was DigitalTutors, you knew you could expect high quality, industry professionals teaching the craft. This isn't the case now that they combined tutorials from both websites. 

I just sat and listened to a guy who was teaching us OUTDATED techniques for Video Editing. The guy who taught it was Joshua Samson and he isn't even a typical, industry professional like you are used to listening to at DigitalTutors.com (when it was separate). 

Watched a few other videos and this was confirmed, there is a lot more muddled down tutorials with wannabe professionals that are teaching outdated techniques or not going in depth in the courses. If you are learning how to do documentary editing in close to only 1 hour, there is something wrong with content and quality of the tutorial. Unfortunately, I am seeing LOTS of this. Very good titles, very bad tutorials.

headline: Expert Authors, but for the most part courses were too short.  It needs to be more hands on that simulates job training since most employers expect you to have concrete experience for any job.
reviewBody: Expert Authors, but for the most part courses were too short.  It needs to be more hands on that simulates job training since most employers expect you to have concrete experience for any job.  It needs to be more of projects of smaller scale that developers will likely perform on their jobs.  Employers basically don't train their employees, but expect them to have array of skills and be ready to go from first day without much supervision at all.  Even if authors have to break it down to part 1-4, since they are the foremost experts in the field, they ought to know what goes on in the job and what duties that needs to be fulfilled.  I consider pluralsight a legitimate job training sites and with proper training, learners will be able to create projects that mimic real world scenarios.  For example, C# and Java courses need to include more real world projects in smaller scale to simulate actual experience.  Now you have Simon Allardice - the expert in Javascript, IOS and Swift...  I would have Simon create apps or projects that will mimic what real world project looks like and how to do it and what pit falls there are.  Freecodecamp does that nicely without expert video training from pluralsight.

headline: 3.5 Good but not Great
reviewBody:
If I just watch the videos the lessons do not stick in my mind.  However it does take the time specified.  

The easiest way to pass your tests is to take notes during the video and then answer the quiz from the notes.  However several of the answers are now wrong in  the latest version of the software.

Giving the correct answers from the latest software loses me points.  So doing the examples during the video is often pointless as it just confuses the course with versioning issues.

Even if the course is with the latest version and I am doing a 5 hour course and it takes me 15 hours to complete there are often details from the beginning of the course I have forgotten by the end of it.
So I need to take notes and do it in two stages.

When I try to do the exercises I waste hours and on occassion over a day to get them working with the latest software VS 2015 and EF 6  and SQL Express 2014 and occasionally I cannot do them at all as there are just too many differences.  

This often doubles or triples the length of the course.  However once completed the excercise from my notes and my knowledge of the latest version I do get a useful grounding in the lesson.

Occasionally, I get stuck in the exercises and because of the differences in environment I cannot spot where my mistake is and I do not want to waste your time with issues that are often stupid typos.

e.g. I am too used to XML rather than http and you should see the bizarre effects you can get:
if instead of writing < i glyphicon glypohicon-world > < / i > you write  < i  glyphicon glypohicon-world / > In my instance I only got 5 distinct instances of the icon instead of the expected 1.

However, comparing the after code with my code did spot that particular issue.  Sometimes they do not.  So overall a useful way of learning new skills but not perfect.

Please keep improving your courses.

headline: Good mix of courses, let down by missing basic features.
reviewBody:
First the good news:
There are A LOT OF GOOD QUALITY COURSES on Pluralsight.com, mostly for technical training.  Some of their course leaders are experts in their field, and adept at making dry topics interesting enough for you to remain interested for (sometimes) 10-12 hours of course content.  

I have found some great courses on .NET, which have helped refresh my technical knowledge, and making development interesting again.  

There are some good 'business professional' courses too, e.g. the PMP Project Management courses, which allow you to count the hours spent on Pluralsight.com towards your certification.  That is a great help.

Downsides:
Some of the tutors are not good, and make no attempt to engage the audience.  Some just read exactly what it says on the slides.  This is pointless.  These courses need to be removed or re-done, as it appears some professionals just use Pluralsight as a way to self-publicise.  

I have not found a way to look at my course history, beyond the 10 'most recent' courses.  This is useless.  I can do 10 courses in a few weeks, but I cannot see beyond that.

Some of the technical courses are useless if you are not on the Plus subscription.  To me, this is like a bait-and-switch.  You'll see technical courses where the leader will say "I'm not going to cover all the code here, you can see what I've done in the exercise files" - but you cannot get the exercise files unless you are a Plus subscriber.  All the poor Normal subscribers are out of luck...  You might not realise you're missing fundamental information until you've spent hours on a course.  Then you cannot complete it.  This needs addressed.

The 'assessments' are like an afterthought on some courses, hardly worth bothering about.  

There doesn't seem to be a way to 'report' a course which is particularly bad.  You can rate it, and comment on the discussions, but that's about it.  You can tell how proud of their course the tutor is by their interaction with subscribers - some are great, providing extra info, going the extra mile.  Some don't bother to respond at all.

All in, it's the best of the bunch for CBT at your own pace.  

Oh, their iPad app is terrible - don't expect to use it for anything, you'll go mad.  And you cannot download more than 30hrs of content for offline viewing.  Which is unfortunate.  They should really have designed their infrastructure a bit better before growing so large.

headline: Review of PluralSight
reviewBody:
It is hard to navigate to my most recent courses using the mobile application. Oftentimes, the titles are truncated in the mobile application instead of being word-wrapped so that I can clearly see which course is Part I versus Part II, etc. The mobile application crashes a lot, inducing me to use the Web application. 

When you use people for whom English is a second language, their accents are often too great a barrier to learning the material. Consequently, I give up on such coarses and move onward. 

You have a lot of good material, but I wish it were presented in the way that Microsoft Virtual Academy presents many, although not all, of their learning seminars - showing two people interacting, discussing the good, bad, or indifferent about theo technology and moving slowly enough to duplicate their code instructions on my computer. I tried taking a C# course, but the instructor moved so fast that during demonstrations I found it hard to duplicate his efforts without rewinding. 

The rewind and fast-forward features need to become more prominent in the interface and allow granular control so that I can move back three seconds exactly, instead of moving the control backward and randomly being stuck having to view the last twenty seconds all over again because the control does not provide granular manipulation. 

The transcripts are abominable. It does not even look like someone tried to get the trascriptions right. Words run together and are misspelled, making it difficult to use that tool to supplement the video. 

I used to be able to download all of the lectures to my iPad for off-WiFi viewing. I looked for that option recently, but could not find it, please bring it back.

When I use PluralSight with my iPad and AppleTv, I have to click play at the beginning of every lecture in a module. I would like to be able to sit on my couch and have the lectures continuously stream until I want to stop, such that I would take some action to stop continuous playback. 

Content: The reason I purchased PluralSight was because I wanted advanced SQL Server 2014 or 2016 material. Although beginning material is helpful sometimes, I primarily watch for an explanation of the concepts associated with an advanced topic.

That's it for now.

headline: Content Very Good, Mobile App Awful
reviewBody:
In almost all cases, the content has been very good. Video covers technical elements much faster and more throughly than books.

The mobile app is frustrating for the following reasons:
- When app opens on iPad, the user is FORCED to wait for a catalog update. The user should never be FORCED to do anything.
- The user should be able to tap once on any part of the video to start/stop. Too often, a second, third, or fourth tap is required, all in the center.
- To be really impressive, Pluralsight could offer a foot pedal to control stop/play, fast forward, and reverse. The videos have no value unless I type in the code myself and play with it. A foot pedal would keep my hands on the keyboard, and relieve me from the infuriating process of taps that don't always register.

headline: Good content, many dull presenters.  Overpriced for some subs.
reviewBody:
There is some really top-class in-depth content here.  Unfortunately, about 4/5 of it is hampered by being presented by the experts - and they are generally really boring and dull.  It's a real challenge to stay interested in a topic when the presenter drones on, repeats slides, and appears to be speaking slowly to try to extend the time of the course.

Look at "Scaling SQL Server 2012" with Glenn Barry.  He repeats the same slides/list of common application architecture faults AT LEAST 6 times before the actual section where he covers them.  You could skip the entire first two modules, and not miss anything.  And you have to speed up his audio to at least 1.3x normal, lest you be put to sleep.

Don't even bother with the Python courses with Robert Smallshire - very dull.  The whole 'Zen of Python' nonsense he perpetuates just puts off any normal developer as it is so pathetic and infantile. 

Top marks however to Miguel Castro, on his Building End-To-End Application course(s).  He keeps the audience engaged, keeps his examples realistic and does not pretend to have all the answers.  He just gives you the benefit of his experience.

As for the cost of the subscription - I would suggest that it is a bit sharp.  I pay $30 per month (2015 prices), with no source code nor slides, and it is a bit of a rip.  Plenty of the courses skip through source, and you cannot code along with them, since you never see the full source they are using.  This to me is bordering on bait and switch.  You have to pay a great deal more to get the full content.    

Also, their iOS app is an absolute abomination, and they should be ashamed.

headline: PluralSight Changed the Way I Learn

Previously, I used to read a bunch of magazines (MSDN Magazine, Windows Developer Pro, SQL Server Magazine, etc.) and a bunch of O'Reilly books.

Now, I spend that same time with PluralSight, and my rate of learning has increased dramatically.  Without it, I never could have learned SharePoint in a very short time (for a project deadline), not to mention WCF, Web Api, advanced Jquery, MVC, Active Directory, Azure, Service Bus, Office 365, advanced CSS, Fiddler, F12 tools, and much more.

headline: Good courses, disappointing technology
reviewBody:

It is easy to search and find a course that
a) covers the subject you are interested in
b) covers it at a level you need i.e. begineer, intermediate and advanced - although some of the courses need to have their levels reviewed (and lowered)

However, Pluralsight need to watch their own courses:
1. The web player on the iPad keeps pausing between sections which is very annoying. You have to reselect the section from the progress bar to get it to play - and sometimes it takes 2-3 attempts to get it to restart.
2. The iPad app doesn't have the history of videos I've watched on other devices (Windows laptop, iPad browser). I've uninstalled the iPad app for that reason.
3. On the website, once you have a playlist you can't drag and drop the items to change the order (I've been watching JavaScript/Angular videos for a couple of months and I think I could write that functionality)
4. Items don't get removed from the playlist once you've watched and/or rated them.

Fix these two things and you'll get 5 stars from me next time!

I often review the lessons I have already studied when I am working on a new project so that I can use and apply exactly what I am learning. My subscription has made the learning of Silverlight (4 years ago) and ASP.NET MVC so much easier for me! I no longer have to try to read a tome of a book just to get going! headline: Great content - android app and chromecast a constant niggle
reviewBody:
Dont have much to say bad about the actual videos - always learn a lot and always new courses added so no problem there.  Particularly like Scott Allen's stuff but most authors are great and know their stuff.  

I have four main problems, so here they are: 
1) On the website itself: when loading video in the browser, sometimes the video does not load correctly and stops in the middle and you have to close the browser and reload.  
2) On the website: when you actually load up the course details and see the course overview with the chapters and episodes, it would be very nice if, when you have already watched some episodes of a chapter, to have the most recently watched chapter episode list automatically open out and the browser scroll down to the next unwatched episode - sounds kind of minor but it's actually pretty annoying after a while.
3) The android app: it is unfortunately unusable, mostly because of the choppy audio which renders most videos unlistenable to.  I will take another opportunity here to plead with Pluralsight to fix this.  As I have mentioned on my review on the Google Play Store, it's a real blemish on Pluralsight's record - cmon guys, it's not like you dont know any tech guys who can help you out with this.  
4) Chromecast: Chromecast is supported on the iPhone (I think), please can this be done for android devices as i love the chromecast and find it really useful.

Apologies if any of the above complaints have been fixed, i havent looked at the android stuff in a few months.

That's it.  I have until this december until my renewal - if the android app is fixed i will probably just renew without thinking, if not, I will be looking at alternatives.

Thanks
Gus

reviewBody:

Only two things I'd like to expect for my use:
The support for video does not completely match my expentations.
Full Chromecast and Linux support would simplyfie my viewing :)

The sound is sometimes flickering, and I have to pause for the video to buffer some data before I can continue, happens on android and pc and both on viewing on the device or streaming.

Minor things I'd value to have in your product:
- Better overview on courses in Android (find by tags, authors etc.)
- Tips on courses I'd might like (others viewed this course also liked this on etc)
- Other payment models, single course payment or one day payment etc.

I love your site, I found it helpful and very useful but it is really annoying when I can use all benefits of it in its fullest capacity.
For example, I like to program side by side while I am watching your videos, and easiest way for me to do it is using tablet as replay source, but all troubles with constant crashing of your app, video and sound not in synchronization etc. make me sad just because you are site about programming and that app isn't well done and it is bad publicity.

headline: Incredible value! I recommend to all developers!
reviewBody:

I recently started a new job that had responsibilities outside of my skill set. I used Pluralsight to "fill the gap" on a few technologies that I had not used and didn't miss a beat at work.

You can spend days wading thru MSDN documentation or use Pluralsight and spend a few hrs.

Well worth the price and I highly recommend to all developers of any skill level!

headline: An essential resource for any developer
reviewBody:
I am a huge fan of Pluralsight, and have been a member for over 6 months. All of the courses I have watched have been high quality and the downloadable resources are a great way to reinforce what you have just learnt.
In particular the ability to "speed up" the courses is essential, I now tend to watch most of the courses at x1.5 and then pause for reflection when I need to.

headline: Great service but...
reviewBody:
I like the variety of content on the site and the instructors explain things very well. The web interface works well and the 8 second rewind is very helpful along with the simple and smooth speed changer.

However it would be nice if you also offered access to Transcender or some other type of exam testing s/w. The simplistic exams that you have at the end of each course are nothing like the real certification exams.  Also, the portable versions (both Apple and Android) do not appear to sync well with the web version.

headline: Pretty good - not great
reviewBody: The courses are, for the most part, very good. I have noticed that 'most' of the instructors are Windows based so things can get a little confusing sometimes. If you are coding along with the instructor, it appears that they do the video and then debug the code. So, you get bugs. No biggie for an instructor. For the rest of us - this can be a really big deal because there are TONS of moving parts and it is difficult to figure out which part is broken.

headline: Needs improving the assessments system
reviewBody: I joined Pluralsight following an advice from a friend and after watching few courses I instantly appreciated the thorough approach, the quality of the information given and the material, however not very impressed by the assessment system. Some courses ask you only 6 questions which is far by ideal because just 2 wrong answer and you fall below the 70% mark required to pass the assessment with lots of frustration, a 10 to 15 questions is more appropriate and also gives the chance to verify much better your understanding of the subject with less frustration. I also use the assessment system as a way to show to potential employers that I'm taking my training seriously and it doesn't really help when your public profile shows the text "Assessment not passed" under a subject you haven't even tried the assessment yet, just because you have finished to watch a course! Simply writing the text "Assessment not attempted yet" gives a completely different message to the viewer and is not rocket science to implement...
